Rep.), most likely due to the fact that it’s all in one large U-shaped building, with short distances, not so much tropical landscaping, more palace like fountains, a great European Café ambience in the courtyard etc. HOTEL ROOMS & BATHROOMS are very nice and well kept, impeccable maid service with “turn down service” with Hershey kisses at night. SERVICE in restaurants and at pool was great, very attentive and fast, no need to tip. We just tipped for extraordinary service plus the maid twice per day (+ bell boy, for room service, driver of airport transportation). I am pregnant and they were almost insulted when you ordered your drinks without alcohol but when I told them why they acted overjoyed and kept congratulating us … POOL is a lot of fun with the sun loungers and the little table nooks near the swim up bar. It was never a problem finding a chair in the shade or sun no matter what time we showed up. But this pool does not intertwine with tropical landscape like at some resorts. The FOOD is very good, with lots of choices. We ate once at each one of the a la carte restaurants and one night at the buffet – almost wished we had done that more often, it was great with lots of almost gourmet choices. The gourmet restaurant Sir Oliver was very good, but didn’t seem “truly” gourmet to us. It was better for example at the Paradisus Punta Cana’s Gourmet Restaurant. We made reservations right on the first day and continued doing that (you can only make two at a time) and didn’t have any problem getting into all restaurants during our week there. The WALK TO 5TH AVE in Playa del Carmen is about 20 min and very nice, although you might want to take a taxi (for $5) during the day, it does get pretty hot … we felt very safe walking even at night and in the dark. There is quite some police presence on 5th Ave and the Riu is in the gated Playacar zone although anyone can walk in, they just check cars more carefully. It seemed like only other tourists were out walking in Playacar, occasional joggers (tourists too?). The walk leads you by some Mayan ruins, if you follow the foot path on the right at the second set of ruins (coming from the hotel zone going towards 5th Ave) down it comes out at more ruins close to the beach. If you want to save money on the TOURS, check out the travel agency Solatino on 5th Ave in Playa del Carmen, they were $10 per person cheaper for the Tulum Explorer (1/2 day tour for $28) and also considerably cheaper on other trips. Be aware of other offers, some are from time-share companies – usually the ones trying really hard to get your attention. No one at Solatino chased us down or followed us out when we didn’t buy the trip on our first visit. When we tried to bargain with our Tour Rep at the hotel, he did offer us a special “Mexican” price on the all day trip to Tulum and Xel-Ha, but said he couldn’t compete with Solatino and advised us to buy the ½ day trip there for that price and confirmed that they are a reputable travel agency. We could always find a COMPUTER at the sports bar (5 stations, one empty one for laptop), although they seemed quite busy. It’s $8 for 1 hour which was just enough for us to check our e-mail almost daily for a week. COMPLAINTS: The BEACH! There is one, but only behind about half of the sea wall and right at the waters edge there are rocks covered with algae = slippery, unsafe to go into the water there and we hardly saw anyone doing it. You can’t walk the beach from there to any of the other resorts, because there is none to the right or the left. You are stuck! That’s what we really disliked most. We loved being able to walk the beach at the other resorts we have been at. You can of course go to any of the other RIU properties, the Playacar is closest or the Palace Mexico, they have a “normal” beach, but it was pretty packed on the sand and in the water. And it’s not that convenient to have to walk there on the street …. So if a beach is important to you, this resort might not be for you. The central AIR-CONDITIONING seemed to be turned off between 3 – 6 am in our room. We woke up several nights in a row around that time really hot, turned our air further down, without any effect. However it would always be cool when we went to bed and when we woke up in the morning (around 12 - 1 am and about 8 am). We asked at the front desk, they said it’s only turned of in the common areas, promised to send someone to look at our room, nothing happened. We were on the top floor, that probably didn’t help. The ANIMATION TEAM is not as active or obnoxious as at some other resorts (where they might not leave you alone until you agree to enter the beer drinking contest …), BUT they are also hard to find unless they have a scheduled activity right then and there. There is no central location where to find them and you might be just out of luck. They don’t have any waterballs you can borrow, there is just one table tennis table out on the beach which seemed to be either occupied when we wanted to play or we couldn’t find anyone to provide us with rackets and a ball (much better e.g. at the Coral Marien in Puerta Plata). They only play louder music at the bar during the scheduled activities like ballroom dancing or water aerobics (both in the pool), it is pretty quiet otherwise. My suitcase didn’t make it there the first day and we didn’t get to the resort after many flight diversions until 10.45 pm, I had packed my toiletries (inc. toothbrush) in the check in luggage because of the new restrictions – well, I thought they would have a toothbrush for me at the front desk possibly – no chance, only at the gift store which was already closed then. I found one there the next morning – for the price of $4-5.

Reviews.Title: “very nice”
Reviews.Author: ChristianAM
Reviews.Content: This is a very nice place to stay. In reading the reviews, I see people complaining about this not living up to the price. That is totally ridiculous. One cannot expect total luxury at an all inclusive resort charging 1000 dollars a week. Anyone expecting total luxury should expect to pay A LOT more in 2006 than this place charges. This was as much as you can get for the price, and quite comfordable. Luxury is the Amanpurri in Phuket, Thailand- try about $750 a night- room only... Mexico is about laid back fun and great weather, and the Riu delivers. Also, for the record, I am not a fun of all inclusives. I prefer independant travel and feel the all inclusive robs you of the cultural experience of visiting foreign countries, but it was a group trip, I relented, and fully enjoyed myself. We stayed at the Riu Riviera for 5 days on a family reunion/holiday. The resort was way more than adequate for our needs. The food was excellent- high quality, good preperation and sufficient variety. Only ate at the Brazilian restaurant, buffet the other nights. It was just better for our group that contained three vegetarians. We also rolled into town for a meal. Totally worth it and highly recommended. The drinks were what I would expect from a top end all inclusive, that is to say anyone will get sick of call brands and Corona in a few days. But, just as I say that, i went on a huge bender the last night in the sports bar, and the cold coronas went down great, so there you go... Everything was served on time and with a smile. The staff was really great, but we did tip well. They totally deserve it. These people work 6 days a week, 12 hours a day at showing us a good time-- a few bucks here and there goes a long way towards helping them support their families and insuring promt service. Regardless, tips or no tips, service was more than adequate. Our room was impecably clean and well apointed, once again, you want luxury and romance, try another spot, but for a clean attractive and comfordable room, look no further. I mean really, the in room liquor dispenser says it all. this place is designed for fun, not hard core romance and indulgence. Oh yeah, room service was pretty horrible, as expected. four choices, all pretty bad. Beach was bad, but that is not the resorts fault. I understand there is a dredging vessel in Cancun that is coming down in January to repair the beaches damaged by hurricanes. There is a dive operation at the resort. they can help you plan trips if you are a diver. Scuba Caribe, good reputable Dive operation, convenient too. If you are a diver, i recommend a day in the Cenotes. Totally unique and beautiful. DO NOT book excursions in the lobby. The concession in the lobby will rip you off. Go across the street to the Plaza Playacar or into town to compare excursion prices. You will save 20%. Funjet is a rip off. Though our trip to Xel-HA and Tulum was fun, we overpaid because we booked it in the lobby. Once again, NOT the hotel's fault. In summary, i thought the riu was a good value, was incredibly clean, great food, great service, comfordable, and close to town. You do not feel trapped at your resort. It is great for groups and families, but couples seeking a romantic hide-away should look elsewhere. Riu Palace Playa Riviera Maya is a very nice resort for people looking for a very nice all inclusive in Mexico.

Reviews.Title: “Our two week stay at the Riu Palace Riviera Maya”
Reviews.Author: Allen_W
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Riu Palace Riviera Maya for two weeks from Dec. 2-16. Last year we stayed at the Riu Palace Mexico for one week by comparison. On the plus side: a. The Riviera Maya is fancier with a very large Lobby, nice bar, beautiful courtyard and pool. b. The rooms were spacious and clean with nice balconies. The air conditioning was quiet and comfortable. There are three maid services each day: cleaning, towel check, turn down the beds. The bottled water was dutifully replenished each day. c. Excellent wait staff. Excellent service staff. We received two calls each week asking if we were satisfied with our room. A problem with our shower fixture was quickly repaired. The reception desk staff were very helpful and polite. They were also invaluable in helping us with taxis, currency exchange and local travel advice. c. The food at the buffet was quite good each day. The three specialty restaurants we visited were all quite enjoyable. On the down side: a. The mixed drinks were not very good. We are convinced ALL the liquor is watered down. Although internationally known brands are available, you must ask for them each time or you will receive local inferior stock. The wine was not watered down. The Chilean Cabernet and the Merlot were very good. The Corona beer was fine. b. There is no beach!! That is, there is no sand at the water's edge. If you want to go into the ocean, you must walk down to the Palace Mexico and use their beach (which is beautiful). This was unexpected and very disappointing. Next year we will stay at the Mexico to make sure we have a proper beach. c. No face cloths in the bathroom. Shabby beach towels. d. All the doors to the rooms slam shut! Wham! The doors are heavy and the closer pumps are set much too strongly. Believe me, it's a real surprise when your neighbor returns at 12:30am and his door slams shut! e. The room's walls and ceilings are not well insulated at all. You hear much more than you want to! The first week we could hear children running above us and toys dropping on the floor. The second week there were no children above us but we could clearly hear and feel much more alarming sounds from the adults. Also, we could clearly hear the TV in the next room whenever it was on. We don't recall having this problem at the Mexico. Keep it in mind. Will we return? Yes, when they rebuild the beach.

Reviews.Title: “Magnificent hotel, but no beach”
Reviews.Author: Danielle/Michel
Reviews.Content: This hotel is very impressive and a true 5 star. My husband and I (both in our late 40s) felt pampered to the hilt. Champagne for breakfast served by waiters in tuxedo and bow ties. Wow!!! One major drawback if you are a beach lover. There is a lot of space for beach chairs, etc. but there is no way you can swim at this resort. The beach is completely eroded with muy problemos ahead. All in all, it was a great holiday, great hotel, great company.

Reviews.Title: “Girls Trip with little kids!”
Reviews.Author: kenzielou1
Reviews.Content: Visited the RPRM with my pregnant friend, her 3 year old niece and my 2 year old daughter. Traveling without our husbands we were a bit nervous. However, we never had any problems, even leaving the resort to do some shopping. We chose not to walk at night (took cabs - $5 to shopping area) but did enjoy walking to the shopping area during daylight (about 20 minutes). The hotel ~ food, beach, pool & room: FOOD: We never dined in the reservations only restaurants on property. It was easier for us to eat at Don Manolos (w/out reservations). The food was good. Lots of variety. Even the meats we decent. We aren't picky eaters though. They had fries and pizza for kids. The ice cream was the best though! The restaurant by the pool was also good. We ordered room service a couple of times. Nothing fancy. They have nachos on the menu and a couple other snack type things. The nachos were ok. Not very authentic tasting, but did the trick when you had the munchies. Beach: It was good for our girls to play on. I was disappointed that the girls couldn't play in the water off the beach though. There is a fence so you either play above it in the sand, or walk down to the tiny beach/water area. There just wasn't any place to put lounge chairs near the water. Pool: Freezing. Way too cold. The 3 year old did good with floaties - but my 2 year old couldn't get in with out me. Hard to relax with it not being kid friendly. Now there is a shallow area where the water chairs are, but it does drop off to deep water. There is a kiddie pool area but it smelled like wet cat so we didn't let them play there. Room: We booked a standard room. If a view is important to you, be sure to pay the extra $$. Our view was of a roof. Not very pretty. We didn't really care though, but if I were traveling with my hubby I would like a nicer view. We never sat on the balcony, because there was really nothing to look at. Beds are hard, but I brought one of those egg crate mattress thingies. That did the trick. The room is a good size and VERY clean. The maids do a great job. We had to remind them daily for towels though and never got wash clothes... The drinks were always good. We aren't heavy drinkers, but found they were never watered down. Infact, I had to throw away a Pina Coloda twice because it was too strong! Location is good. We booked through Worry Free and had the airport transfers included. Our hotel was the first stop to be dropped off. When it was time to go back to the airport, we were the last to be picked up. I think this is a good place to get away with a friend. It's not really my cup of tea for a romantic getaway though. Lots of families and kids - which was great for this trip. I would have rated higher if the pool were more kid friendly for younger travelers. Also the standard rooms have lousy views (unless you pay for an upgrade, or get lucky with one on arrival). I just want to note that incase a view is important to you. Some resorts have good standard views. Unless you think rooftops are pretty, pay extra here! I also like to see the ocean when staying a beachfront resort. There aren't many rooms at this resort that have that. The big focus is the courtyard and pool.

Reviews.Title: “Solid 4 star not a 5!”
Reviews.Author: elf.dml
Reviews.Content: This hotel is a beautiful resort ,alot of good amenities but not a 5 star hotel, for us its all in the details... Good: 1) incredible lobby with ample seating areas and elegant decor 2) wow! the pool, huge and integrated jacuzzi jets in a few areas that had tables for drinks and seating for a large group, plenty of lounge chairs w/pads, alot of pool entrances/steps so everyone isn't crowded in one point of entry, a bartender that travels the pool and will mix your drink at your lounger + plenty of girls taking orders 3) good choice of restaurants 4) jr.suites are large with plenty of storage, marble baths and balcony 5) food and bev. galore, large selection at buffets, they had beef wellington and lobster almost every night+ a pasta bar that Heddy will make you whatever selection a pasta w/ different sauces 6) daytime activities in pool 7) fitness center open 7am-8pm, good for most but my husband works out with free weights(none) and only 2 treadmills, a good selection of other machines but everyone goes for the treadmills so arrive early! The not so good: 1) towels!!! in the bathroom and by the pool. Bathroom, only 1x did we get washclothes(always an excuse...), 2x handtowels, plenty of bath towels but they were stained and tatered, for only being open less than 1 year, not so good, looked like they cleaned with the same towels they gave us to bath. 2) toiletries, bring you own thank god I did, the shampoo/ conditioner and soap are a joke, little plastic bottles/ Holiday Inn ish 3) sportsbar? again Holiday Inn ish 4) check in was like a hurd of cattle 5) beverages, water and pop one step above room temp. so ask for alot of ice. The mixed drinks/frozen, not a good consistency, watery, (absolute vodka was top shelf) we stuck to red wine which they do have a great Chiliean cabernet. 6) BEACH...terrible entry to ocean, dangerous, good for laying out on ,that's it You may think we are being picky but for those looking for a 5 star, high class hotel/resort this may not be the hotel for you. great for singles, young couples, couples with kids, not romantic for the 30+ married couple looking for and willing to pay for 5 star.

Reviews.Title: “What's not to love!”
Reviews.Author: luvztravel
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a week at the Riu Palace Riviera Maya. I consulted the reviews extensively before leaving so I thought I'd submit my own. Generally - This hotel is absolutely beautiful. Ceramic tile, marble, gorgeous wood trimming and lovely decor. The layout is perfect. The transition from the hotel/ courtyard to the pool to the beach is open and easy and breathtaking. The staff work tirelessy to ensure that every surface is always clean. (And they always stop what they're doing to say "hola" with a huge smile). Rooms - We were fortunate to get a couryard room (2104) - we could see everything - ocean, pool the main building and all the interesting people walking by. The layout was great. Lots of room to hang up clothes and put them away so we didn't have to look at our suitcases all week. Our room was done 2X a day - more thoroughly during the day with turn down service at night. Fridge stocked daily and when we ran out of vodka, it was replaced within 15 minutes of our call to the front desk. We even got a few towels critters throughout the week!! Service - Unbelievable. Every bartender, front desk person, restaurant staff member was friendly and accomodating. And I can't even begin to imagine how many people are employed at the resort to make it function so smoothly. There were employees everywhere!! Amazing. Pool - very pretty - great layout - nice pool bar. I'm not a pool person when I'm in the Caribbean, so we didn't hang out there - but from what I could see - tonz of chairs!! Beach - okay - lets get this straight. There is a very large upper beach area with tons of trees on the sides and an open area in the middle. Huge - open - beautiful with a wonderful view of the sea. It is the widest and most beautiful along the playacar area. No crowding and no shortage of chairs - probably two for every person and the resort was full. BUT - there is NO gradual sand entry into the ocean. It has been washed away at this resort and at a number of others down the coastline - eg. there were palapas at the resort two down that were basically in the ocean where the beach once was. Even Royal Hideaway were crammed in like sardines on what little beach there was in front of that hotel. As you work your way down, the beaches are less eroded and easy to access. What we did was swim at either the little beach to the left or the little beach to the right of the hotel. Or we took a nice long walk down to a sandier area. Not ideal - but we made the best of it. No question that the beach in front of Riu Palace Mexico has more sand access - but the beach was crammed with chairs and I didn't think that the transition from hotel to pool to beach was as pretty or easy. (But this resort is also beautiful!!) In my view the beach down this entire strip of hotels cannot compete with Turks and Caicos, Paradise Island or Punta Cana - but every place is different and we thoroughly enjoyed the area. Food - breakfast and lunch buffets were great. Loved eating lunch upstairs at Chilis and looking out at the beautiful sea. Variety was great. Always fresh and service was good. The restaurants were good, for the most part. Gourmet was the best (order the seafood entree - shrimps and scallops). Japanese was nice and we had a great steak at Chili's - order the rib-eye meduim rare - nice grillled flavour). The Mexican restaurant was terrible. Service and food were bad for us. Maybe it was a bad night. We skipped our reservation at the Brazilian and had dinner in Playa del Carmen. Absolutely fabulous meal - appetizer, salad and fresh seafood dishes prepared at the table, two cervesas each and our bill was $50 u.s.!! Hard to beat that - with some lovely live Mexican music in the background!! We only had dinner at the buffet once and it was good. Spa/ gym - used the gym twice - very clean and well air conditioned. Equipment in good shape for a busy resort. Didn't use the spa but it looked beautiful. Overall - we had a great week. Only one disappointing meal out of 21!! Loved walking into Playa and enjoying the local scene - bars, local music etc. Felt very safe at all times. Did one excursion to ruins, a sink hole and a Mayan village. Very cool. Great internet access in the sports bar - kept in touch with our kids that way. Wonderful week - I'd go back in a heartbeat.

Reviews.Title: “Riu Palace Riviera Maya - Our Second Home”
Reviews.Author: JMambo
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed in RPRM in October'06 for two weeks. From the moment we walked into the hotel lobby when we arrived untill the very last minute of our stay we felt welcomed and looked after. We found the hotel staff very friendly and we felt that they couldn't do enough for us day and night. Food - very good! Certain things didn't taste "right", but food is all about what your preferences are and what you are used to, but there was always a choice, believe me you won't be hungry. Drink - all I can say is that all brands are top shelf and bartenders at RPRM know their stuff! Rooms - we had a lovely room toward the ocean with a court yard view. It was a top floor room and we had a fab view from our balcony. We also found that our room was cleaned a couple of times a day and the room service was very good too. Beach & Pool - great! Very clean, plently of sunbeds, very good bar servcie round the pool. SPA - I found spa very good too, I had a few treatments there during my stay and was very impressed. Bottom line is -- we had a great time at RPRM, we met some nice people while we were there and the only sad moment was the the moment when we had to leave the Palace to go back. Would we go back - ABSOLUTELY -- DEFINITELY -- YES!

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Riu Palace Riviera Maya”
Reviews.Author: thegarden
Reviews.Content: We spent five days in November at the Riu Palace Riviera Maya. Accomodations were wonderful, service was excellent, and the resort was beautiful. We would visit again!

Reviews.Title: “A great disappointment”
Reviews.Author: sanmartino
Reviews.Content: This is the letter I sent to the General Manager of the property and cc to the travel agency: Mr. Oswald Ponnette: I regret that I have to write this letter, Mr. Ponnette, but our recent stay at the Riu Palace Riviera Maya was extremely disappointing. First of all, the hotel is expensive and, thus, needs to live up to the standard of those prices to be worth what you are charging. I have worked for Marriott International and the Four Seasons so I believe I know what price versus quality is all about in a hotel. Our room (#1011) had a view of about ten meters of grass and the back of the next building. We requested to move but were told there was nothing available. I find that difficult to believe. Food. Although the buffets were adequate, they certainly were not excellent and, again, at these prices we expected excellent. When we attempted to reserve a table for Friday evening we were told everything was full. This was @ 2:30 in the afternoon. You must reconsider the math. Perhaps you need more seatings at these theme restaurants but I don't understand how I can utilize the benefits of this luxury resort if I can't even get a table at a restaurant. Did you know that we were part of a wedding group that booked 31 rooms at the hotel? That's a significant amount and, yet, it does not appear that extra efforts were made to accommodate us (i.e., rooms with views). There was no information when we checked in regarding the wedding such as early gatherings, rehearsal dinner and so. This might sound petty, but with everything else I feel it needs stating. When housekeeping cleans my room and takes the open bars of soap, I think it's only obvious to replace them with new soap. No, instead our soap was taken and none was replaced. Also, our in-room liquor dispenser was never refilled, even though I asked three different hotel employees to do so. And, is there a definitive policy on gratuities because many of your bar staff were accepting tips. Mr. Ponnette, I want to say that Oscar and Robert at the front desk did the best they could to appease my wife and I but the overall experience (again, for the price) was very poor. I would like to hear what you have to say. A copy of this letter is being forwarded to the travel agent that arranged this wedding trip. I told her that the Riu Palace is a new property and perhaps she shouldn't book it until she knew that they were operating up to expectations. Thank you for taking the time to respond.

Reviews.Title: “Don't let negatives affect your decision”
Reviews.Author: Scooterwho
Reviews.Content: Just back from Riu Palace Riviera Maya (RPRM) 10/26-11/2/06 and truly enjoyed our visit. The new Palace has a more spacious feel in common areas than the Riu Palace Mexico (RPMexico). Either way, it continued to provide the same high quality service received on previous visits. Wait staff were great. Elevia was a dear at breakfast. Luciano and Nicholas made lunch enjoyable and ensured our glasses were always filled. We even met Tino (Faustino) back from Cabo San Lucas. He started as a bartender at Yucatan, moved to RPMexico, then on the Cabo San Lucas. We have watched his career grow in his time at the Resorts and glad to see he is doing so well. Stepahnie (orignally Public Relations rep at RPMexico during Wilma fiasco) is now Assistant Manager at RPRM. I have read numerous reports that state "the beach is too small". The beach is fine. It is protected by bulkhead with an ocean beach in front. Why anyone thinks the beach in front of the poolbar is not ocean front, I haven't figured out. A gentleman from Holland and I agreed the pool and beach were great. Shade is provided by palms and it does move with the sun. My husband and I had the luxury of moving our lounges to follow the shade as the sun moved on the horizon. I'd give the beach and pool a 10. Another complaint has been the lack of a beach bar. Considering the depth of the beach and the pool bar location, a beach bar is unnecessary. I have stayed at Riu Palace Mexico three times and walking to the beach bar is actually further than travel to the pool bar on RPRM. Pool bar service another 10. The pool is fantastic. The view of the ocean is always fun. Food has changed. We used to love the buffet. The variety was sufficient to satisfy almost every day of the stay. The buffet is somewhat smaller than at RPMexico, but it does have five fully staffed ala carte restaurants you can chose from for dinner. Breakfast and lunch was great. Dinner at the ala carte restaurants the only controlled portion menu. I spent one day walking from the beach to Chili's "grazing" on fish, beef, and mussels. Fruit always topped off the meal or filled the munching instinct. For those who may be interested, RPRM does have a piano bar and Cristobal does a good job playing music while few listen. The sad part is the room is so large if you're not looking for him, you may miss him. He'll take requests and play it if he has it available. Nice to see. Resort has removed the chapel at RPMexico and replaced it with a sports bar. Strangely, it always seemed to have people in it so I guess there is a need. Not one of my highlights. Only trip was with Iguana Boats Tour to Ek Balam and Rios Largartos. If you don't mind riding for four hours to get to the river, it's a great trip. We truly enjoyed seeing American crocodiles and birds (eagles, hurons, pelicans, and most importantly pink flamingos, real ones) in the wild, riding in the boats, eating a delicious fish lunch in a sleepy fishing village (truly) and seeing the "new" ruins of Ek Balam. If anyone would like more info, let me know. I thought it was great. Only major inconvenience that seems to be common complaint right now was the key cards and readers used for room. It took four sets of key cards and a change to the reader before we got into our room easily. We also got an individual tutoring by a maintenance person who taught us the "secret handshake". When brought up to hotel staff, the problem was acknowledged and is being pursued. Not much more I can say about that. We had a great time. We loved our courtyard room and view of the Ocean. We'd go back in a minute, but will have to wait until we save enough to go back next year

Reviews.Title: “Great time at Riviera Maya”
Reviews.Author: fly2sun
Reviews.Content: We just got back from the Riu Palace Riviera Maya and had a fantastic time. We would definitely go back and couldn't understand why the resort didn't have better reviews on Trip Advisor than it did. Property: The hotel was very beautiful and in our opinion the most beautiful of all the 5 Riu's in the area including the Palace Mexico. Everything was brand new and the decor was done much better. It had a clean look and feel overall from the lobby to the courtyard area, the pool and beach. Loved the layout. Service: We have absolutely no complaints about this. We were tended to each and every time it was required and we felt the staff were sincere in their friendliness and willingness to help. In fact, we felt that way about the locals in general. Some times were busier than others for the staff in which case it was understandable that there would be a delay (for example: clearing the table or taking a drink order at Chili's) but this happened twice in a week and was quickly rectified when brought to their attention. The wait staff at the restaurants were awesome and maid service as well as those stocking the bar did a great job. Room: My husband and I slept fine on the firm mattress but I can understand why this type of mattress would be something bothersome for people. The layout of the room was great, had a courtyard view. The door was a little hard to open, as someone wrote about previously, there is a trick to it. The jacuzzi worked fine. The only BUT in this whole review is watch out for mold in the room. It is unbelievably humid at the resort so this is an unfortunate thing that may happen. The cleaning staff does their best to keep on top of it but this should be mentioned to management. Beach and Pool: Very clean beach and no problems finding a place to park. The pool was also very nice and there were more people here than on the beach but we never had a problem finding spots. The pool bar was great and made the best drinks compared to the other bars. The water at the beach was a gorgeous turquoise although it can be rocky at parts. Food: We ate at the Brazilian (great for meat lovers), Mexican and Japanese restaurants, Sir Oliver's, Chili's and Don Manolo. Sir Oliver's was our favourite. Crab bisque and the seafood entree with scallop and shrimp were delish. Mexican was our least favourite but we expected a lot from them. All the food was prepared well, tasted good and was good quality. We had no issues with the food and the only time we needed Pepto Bismol was when we ate a taco we got in town. However, if you are looking to get the same type of food you would get at a top restaurant in North America, you won't get it. This is what I think people (who wrote bad reviews about the food) were expecting. You will have a good selection of nice meals. All in all: We loved it. People were great. We felt safe. There's some good shopping in Playa del Carmen (20-25 minutes walk) and in the Playacar Shopping Centre (under 10 minutes walk). Unless you shop at the hotel gift store, prices were all pretty reasonable.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing resort - impeccable service! Don't expect perfect weather....”
Reviews.Author: ang4unc
Reviews.Content: We just got back for 8 nights staying at the Hotel Palace Riviera Maya and it was wonderful and relaxing. My husband and I went with his parents to celebrate our 3 years anniversary. We stayed Oct. 30-Nov. 7. Also, sorry this is so long, but full of our insightful tips and info... If there was one thing that could have been better it would be the weather - it was rainy/cloudy about 60% of the time. And it is hurricane season, (so what did we expect?) but I wish it was a tad sunnier or we got luckier - there was a few storms that took a couple days to subside. If I could change one thing it would be to pay the higher price and go during the best weather (March/April), then we would’ve definitely gotten our money's worth. It was frustrating going out to the pool getting all your gear and sunblock on and then everyone running in all frantic because of the pouring rain. Your vacation is either mostly inside or in your room if you go during this time - honestly....Be aware of the weather!! It was muggy and wet it seemed like the whole time. I too am one of those people that read tripadvisor.com frantically and wanted to go to the best place in Playa del Carmen. We had already been to Cancun twice and never here, so we decided to try it out. If you are wondering about whether or not to go to the other Rius - this is by far the best one and you will pay for it. It is GORGEOUS and like a palace when you see it. The other Riu's are just a few blocks down the street and nothing like the Riu Palace Riviera Maya in terms of cleanliness, bars, ambience, class, style, decorating...looked to us like our hotel was by far better than the others. We walked over to the Riu Tequila because we heard they had a good sports bar and we were pretty disappointed, they do not. Here are some first tips that I want to advise everyone, that will definitely make your trip better. 1. Figure out your ground transportation! We booked out stay directly through Riu and the transportation is included with them. BUT – they fail to give you any further information on getting the transportation organized. You are to email them directly and let them know your flight information so they can have someone picking you up. We did that thinking that everything was fine and when we got to the Cancun airport it was a mess. You almost feel like a celebrity because so many people are wanting to give you rides, sell you tours, talk to you, bring you over here, etc. etc…The only information about our transportation was in small fine print on our email reservation and it was provided by a company called Hotel Beds (don’t ask me what kind of name this is…??) So of course nobody knows who Hotel Beds is or where they are located and we are directed to an Information Desk – which is not an information desk, but a lady trying to sell us a trip and golf. Great. Do not stop by the Information desk on the left after baggage claim. So, we eventually walk through the madness and find a sign around the corner called Hotel Beds…(yea right nobody knew where it was…). They did not have any of our information and the only reason we got a ride to the Riu was because I showed him our email reservation from the hotel where it said Hotel Beds reallllly small. Good, got a ride. Our ride was awful! We were in a van with two other couples and had to drop them off on the way. Okay, no big deal…at first. We turn into some road off the highway and go down, seriously, the worst road I have ever driven on in my life. Personally, I would have never even taken a 4-wheeler through this road and we took this van. I was so scared and my husband almost told him to not take us down this road and to stop. We turned in and it was sooo muddy and big big deep potholes everywhere full of mud and water. There was zero signage as to where we were going and no road lights or anything. We had no idea where we were going. It was all mud too, no pavement. The road should have only been taken us less then 5 minutes to drop these people off, but it took us 45 min. there and back . Our driver drove so slow through this road, inched through these potholes and was all over the road trying to avoid everything, which did not work because the entire road was so bad – mind you it was also dark, we were in the middle of the jungle and ready to get to our destination. I couldn’t believe it. This hotel If you are staying there, don't. When we finally got to this hotel these poor people got out and I think they were pretty embarrassed about booking this place already and about ready to cry. Anyways, this was how our trip started….then the entire trip the door of the van isn’t shut and is clanging and banging the whole hour drive. It was very irritating and loud. Our driver made no effort to get out of the van or pull over to fix it. So, it was definitely a relief to get to the Riu. My in-laws were there with a melted frozen margaritas waiting for us. Oh and before I forget….about your transportation. There are “Hotel Beds” representatives in the hotel throughout the week and when you get there they want you to come downstairs and meet with them. Well, we were so frustrated, the last thing we wanted to do was sit and talk to these people….and my in-laws said you didn’t have to because all they do is try and sell you stuff. They were right…we saw so many couples sitting with travel agencies and the “Hotel Beds” people trying to sell them stuff and they were all looking pissed. You don’t have to do this! Just find a representative the day before you leave and arrange your transportation to go home and don’t even sit down on the couch! This is something else they fail to tell you…if you don’t arrange your transportation to leave who knows what happens. Nobody told us this. My in-laws left a day early and had already arranged to have a taxi take them to the airport because they didn’t want to deal with the Hotel Beds people….but just to be curious we asked them if they have transportation anyways and they said no because they didn’t arrange it the day before…okay, that would have been nice to know..... 2. Tip the resort employees. These people all work very hard and the resort has 5-star service. Honestly, if you want the best service though, give these hard working people 20 pesos and watch the difference. You will get better drinks, better alcohol, better room service, everything if you just tip. I understand that this is an All-Inclusive and in your mind you have already paid for your trip, but these people make barely $60 or less usd a week and they work their tails off. They only get one day off a week and usually work 10-12 hour shifts! Most of them live far from the resort so they have to figure out their transportation as well. I just think it’s good etiquette and you will feel better knowing that you are helping them out. We tipped our bartenders usually about 20 pesos ($2 usd) for every couple/few rounds and our room service $5-10 every couple days. At breakfast and lunch about $2-4 and at dinner $5-10. 3. Do not get suckered into going to those timeshare or resort option buying seminars. I won’t go all into this because it would take me forever to vent, but we ended up going into a shop on Fifth Ave. that sold tours and he gave us a great deal on fishing and golf for our family if we attended a 45 min. seminar to buy a timeshare. We ended up saving about $500 overall on the whole thing, so we thought, “No big deal it’ll be worth it and we would never buy one anyways….” Let’s just do this, go on our trip and golf and it’s raining anyways. Well, the entire thing was a joke and they were the most pressuring people I’ve ever met in my life and the majority of them were Americans! It was crazy – do not go to a Mayan Resorts seminar or even go near these people. We almost didn’t get our fishing and golf that we were promised and paid for and they lied so many times. They said 7 minute ride – it was 30 minutes. They said 5 hour deep sea fishing trip – it was not deep sea fishing and we caught two small barracudas and ended it early…they said 45 min. presentation, it was 3 hours. They said 18-hole Jack Nicklaus golf course…par 3 course Jack Nicklaus course (maybe not...?) and they failed to pay for transportation home which was promised. We are going to find people responsible for this company and are writing a big long letter to them, but otherwise steer clear! The only good thing about it was that we saved a lot of money, learned our lesson and it was raining that day so we didn’t have any major plans. My father-in-law gets seasick anyways and we had already golfed at a better 18-hole course the day before. 4. Definitely go into Playa del Carmen downtown and check out Fifth Ave. Some people say that you shouldn’t leave the resort, but I think you definitely should otherwise you might get bored and it’s so worth it. There are so many cute and trendy restaurants and shopping on Fifth Ave. It is safe and a neat experience. We highly recommend doing this during the day and night. It is so neat to see all the people walking and to see how this city is trying to make it work. They are doing a great job down here and I look forward to coming back and even seeing more and how it will be improved. We watched football at a great Sports bar on Sunday and Monday night called EndZone (EZ) Sports bar ([--]) and also ate at Casa Agua and Playasia. Playasia is a part of the BlueParrot Hotel and had the best atmosphere we have ever seen in a restaurant. They had a mix of everything and sushi. We love sushi and didn’t see any other sushi restaurants except this one. We ate at Casa Agua and it was great…the food and drinks were average, but the service was awesome. We had the best waiter and he gave us a free drink and dessert because we were celebrating our 3-year anniversary. They have awesome upstairs dining where you can overlook Fifth Ave. I will highlight some areas of the resort now. BEACH: The beach is great, but it’s setup a little ackward and it’s kind of hard to describe and I never understood until I got there. They don’t have a big beach area that you can run from and into the water…it’s divided by a big concrete sea wall ? I don’t know if that is what it’s called, but there is an extremely large area of sand with the palm trees for laying out on and then closer to the ocean it is cut off by a fence on top of a wall to look over. (Like you are on top of the retaining wall looking down at the water…) You go down a set of stairs on the right and then there is a teeny beach (you don’t lay on this one) and you swim into the ocean. They do this because of the high and low tide I think. There was one day where we had a red flag and nobody could go swimming because the water was right next to the wall and the waves were rough. Then on the left side of the beach you can lay more close to the water, (the wall fades) but there are rocks and you don’t swim there, but you can lay on chairs there. I think the whole setup is great because the area where there is sand allows people just to look over the fence at the ocean and swimmers and there are some people playing soccer with their kids (we only saw this once) or this way you have a nice open view of the gorgeous water. The beach/sand area is so huge, there are an abundance of chairs and areas for privacy and sun – it’s overwhelming. You will always find a place to lay out or even be close to the water to hear the waves. It’s gorgeous. If you are into a beach where it runs straight into the ocean, this is not it….but it’s is essentially the same thing once you get past the wall. I hope this gives you an idea of what it’s like. KIDS vs. TEENAGERS: There are some kids around, but they are not bad at all. They are all very cute too and their parents are watching them like hawks too. It was cute to see some of the kids running around playing, but they were never a distration. There are some teenagers, but they were all with their parents...there was a family though I think from Brazil and their kids were drinking, wearing g-string bikinis..these girls were like 14!! I coudln't believe it...maybe that is the way it is there... FOOD: This is like a food marathon resort. There is SO much food it’s overwhelming and after you leave you will have gained 10 pounds (or at least it feels like it now…). They display the food so beautifully and some nights they make some serious food sculptures that were the best I've ever seen in my life. The resort offers a buffet for breakfast, lunch (at Chili's) and dinner and then 5 or so various restaurants to dine at night. There was a Japanese, Brazilian, Mexican, Gourmet and Steakhouse restaurant (I think that was all of them). We never ate at the Gourment (Sir Oliver’s), but our favorite was the Steakhouse. Otherwise, personally we did not think the restaurants were that good. We are avid sushi eaters and the place of sushi they give is is "okay"...for Mexico. Otherwise, we didn't really LOVE anything at the restaurants. We like the buffet better... Most of the restaurants have food where some of it, I have no idea what it is…the items are so far off of what we would normally eat in the US. The Mexican is not really Mexican food (I am from New Mexico and we have the best Mexican food) – the closest thing to Mexican that we saw was the “burritas”, which were only bean and the guacamole and pico that we got from the salad bar. They did have a chalupa type tostada that was more Mexican that tasted pretty good. Otherwise, our favorite was the buffets they offered. There is so much food and it is all presented so well. I am not usually a picky eater, but some of the food is bland and not much flavor. I think that is how it is though in most of these all-inclusive resorts. There are some things that you can find that taste really good, but otherwise it seems they fail to add sugar or spices to their food. I guess it’s just a matter of experiencing it and finding what you like best. My favorite was the ice cream – they have better ice cream than I have ever tasted here in the states! But, their desserts are SO bland. The guacamole is great (with added salt) and their pico de gallo. Excellent coffee and cappuchinos after dinner were awesome. They have great mimosas and chips too… SERVICE: The service everywhere is phenomenal. I was really overwhelmed and how prompt the service was and how friendly all the staff was. They were all very accommodating and would definitely go out of their way to make your stay perfect. We asked for a bottle of champagne and orange juice (I love champagne) sent to our room for our anniversary and they were more than willing to do that. We also called ahead and had the head chef make a cake for my husband for his birthday and after dinner they all brought it out and sang Happy Birthday to him. It was great! They are quick to get you water, coffee, your dirty plate, open your chair, place your napkin on your lap, get you another drink, anything. If you really want service that includes special treatment definitely tip. But…if you are ordering drink after drink or your waiter/waitress fails to speed up your order or come around often, maybe it’s because you don’t tip. Really. We never ordered room service though, so I can’t comment on how well that was. SPA/GYM: My mother-in-law and I went and got facials and they were awesome! Approx. $90-100 each for 1 hour. We were able to get them at the same time, in the same room and they were wonderful. I even fell asleep...don't ask me how and this has never happened before. The hot tub and jacuzzi's where in the spa too. All the spa services are not included, so everything you must pay for...(except the sauna and hot tub). My husband and I love to exercise and we visited the gym once this entire trip. They have decent equipment, but nothing like what we have here. A few treadmills, stairclimber, two bikes and an elliptical trainer. It's not the best equipment and kind of ackward to use....plus we want exercise from walking and shopping or swimming. They have weight machines and some mats to stretch. ROOM: The room was beautiful. All over the halls and rooms there is dark cherry wood doors, bed, paneling, furnishings and marble tile floor. It’s actually pretty amazing they have all this wood everywhere with how humid it is. The minibar was stocked with drinks, except bottled water - we did have to ask for it and they gave it to us the rest of the week. There are rooms that face the outside hotel and those that face the courtyard. My in-laws had an outside view, but the next night upgraded to a courtyard room. We had been given an outside view room, but decided to stay there because it was more private. When you have an inside room you have to listen to all the noise at night at the discoclub and there is more going on. They said that there was a lot of noise that you can hear at night and they were even in the middle area…I’m sure if you are at the end closer to the pool it’s not as loud. We also wanted a king bed, but were given two double beds pushed together. At first we were going to change, but actually liked it. We have a queen at home (with a dog), so we were used to being more cramped and it was nice to have that space on our vacation – don’t get me wrong, it’s not like we don’t like sleeping together, but this was a change of pace for us to have our own extra space. And we cuddled sometimes… We tipped our room service and always got two decorated animals and they cleaned everything so well. We only had one bad smelling pillow (??) and they took it away immediately. Our keys didn’t work once either because I think they checked out our parents on accident and they fixed it right away. The bathroom is huge and everything was nice, but be careful of the shower because it is slippery and not very long. On my first night the water temp changed real fast and I stepped back and slipped. I fell back and hit my elbow so hard on the marble tub. I had a big bruised hurting elbow the rest of the trip. Our bathtub was short and it raises up if you take a step back, so be careful….ugh… Our view wasn’t bad on the outside, it faced another hotel (The Reef) and it was pretty…we had a teeny view of the ocean far away, but it was fine for us, we didn't spend any time on the balcony anyways. The A/C worked great too. The only complaint was that the beds are very hard…TIP: You can ask the front desk for those egg crate foam pads and if they have any they will put them under you sheets…it definitely made it much better. POOL: The pool was excellent – there are three different pools connected and on each side there are little tile beds to lay on where you are half in and half out of the water. One pool is above the others that so pretty, it looks like it runs into the ocean…then below is the big pool and the side of that are the tile beds, and then the last pool where they have inlets with a pool booth and table (so neat), jacuzzi inlets, and then the pool bar. I thought it was perfect. The sides where there was those tile beds half in and out of water wasn’t very private though because there was a lot of people sitting on them mingling and drinking. (Which is fine sometimes, but it’s nice to have some space and peace sometimes…) If the weather is nice expect all the lounge chairs to be taken that are closest to the pool. There will be more chairs available, but usually we had to go looking for them and they were 3 rows of lounge chairs back. Twice we got some chairs close to the pool and that was nice. We played water volleyball once and I swam around the most. There are many people that go to these resorts seriously just to marathon read and layout and most of them have such bad sun damage. They are the ones that claim their lounge chairs early and all day. The pool bar (Daiquiri) was the best bar by far. All the bartenders are having fun and will give everyone shots. In a matter of 20 min. once we had 4 shots and 3 awesome strong drinks (we also tipped) and were feeling pretty good. The best bartender is little Juan – he will dance for you, have fun, get you anything you need. He also speaks good English and tries to learn more. The bartenders make the most money in the pool bar, so they enjoy working there best…(little secret I discovered). Sometimes the animation group got a little annoying, but they are just trying to get people involved and having fun. They play house music every now and again and want everyone to get into it. They are dancing, wear funny costumes to start a dance on the beach, throw each other into the pool and play games. BARS: Well, there are like 5 bars in the resort, but don’t expect them to be the “happening fun bar”. We are in our late 20’s, early 30’s and were looking for more of a fun bar and were pretty disappointed at the club/bars here at the Riu. We never really spent much time at the discoclub or that bar because it looked very cheesy…there was some shows and karaoke, but it didn’t look fun so we never went back. There were some people dancing, but just not our style or age. The best bar was the pool bar to us, they had more fun and all of us were having a good time getting to know each other. There was a sportsbar in the main lobby, but that is not even really a sports bar. To play any of the games it’s pretty expensive – something like $4. They have the internet in there, so we were in there usually everyday just to use the internet real quick. They have pool, games, snacks and annoying air hockey. When anyone would start to play this we would leave as soon as we could because it was so loud and you couldn’t even hear each other talk. They need to take out this game, seriously. This is not even remotely close to a sports bar, it’s just another bar at the resort where they hang up some jerseys. They had no idea when American Football came on and didn’t even have soccer games going. We are big football/fantasy football fans and ended up going into the town to watch football at EZ Sportsbar. Much better and the owner is great! There is a bar in the lobby which was pleasant and so cute, we enjoyed sitting in there a couple times to get a drink as we passed or to wait for our dinner reservations. The views by the windows are great to look over the courtyard. Definitely check out the Parrot Club, Senor Frogs downtown if you are looking for a club/dance type bar…we are not big dancers either, but it was a cool place to hang out. There are a few more fun bars downtown though – much better than the Riu for entertainment and it’s only a $5 cab ride. Everyone says you can walk into the town…yes, maybe during the day, but do not walk at night…it is too far and sometimes we weren’t even sure exactly where we were. SHOPPING: You have to go down to Fifth Ave for shopping or two blocks down from the hotel (opposite from the town) there is a little shopping center called Playa Plaza. I didn't even know it was there until 5 days of being there! It was cute and we bought a lot of stuff there. WATERSPORTS: The watersports they offered were okay, they definitely didn’t go out of their way to promote them…and I think it’s because they don’t get paid and have to work. It is part of the all-inclusive plan. If the weather was better we would have tried it all….you have to pay extra for certain things like the banana boat, scuba diving, jet skis and someone with you when you sail. We ended up kayaking and that was fun and got some boogieboards to float around on. I think that you should definitely try it all though, the sailing, bicycle boats, kayaking, scuba, snorkeling…We were going to sail, but didn’t really know how and saw a sailboat overturned and got scared…haha Otherwise, this is an excellent hotel! I wish we honestly didn’t stay as long as we did, 8 nights, 9 days…we were so ready to come home and be in America. I enjoy the culture differences, but got to the point where I was tired of people trying to sell me stuff and wished I could speak Spanish better. At the beginning of the trip I was like, "Hi! No, we are not interested now...maybe later...thanks, bye, take care...."...then at the end I was like, "No - no deal. I don't want it." I wish we had stayed 6 nights. It really makes you miss home and appreciate everything that we have here in our great country. What a great place to stay though and service was wonderful! If we come back we will probably try another hotel, just to see something different, but only because we like other/new places. If you have any questions about the resort though email me: princesslusk@hotmail.com

Reviews.Title: “Good, but not great”
Reviews.Author: darrennelson
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Riu Palace from Oct. 29 to Nov. 5th. After reading numerous reviews before leaving I was a little worried about the service and food to expect but it all turned out great. We travel to a sunny destination at least once per year with our last trips being the Iberostar Lindo in the same area, as well as Secrets and Paradisus in Punta Cana. Overall, I would say a good visit ... not excellent but will explain more. Location: The resort is in a great spot, close walk into Playa del Carmen. One thing to note is even though you can visit the other Riu locations, they are a sort distance away. The other Riu Palace is connected to some of the resorts if that is important for you. Check-in: Check-in was easy/fast. We had no room at arrival as we arrived quite early but just took a quick nap on the beach until the room was ready. I would reccommend to ask for an upgraded room. If anything is available, they will give it to you as the courtyard room views are much nicer than the outside rooms. 5 out of 5 Room: The room was nice, nothing fancy. A little smaller than I expected but nice overall. The mini fridge was stocked daily, and we were amazed at the cleaing service. The room was very clean, and was always done at a good time. As well, they came around so often for new towels, we were feeling guilty when they were not being re-used. 4 out of 5 Restaurants: We had no problem getting reservations for the restaurants which are at either 6:30pm or 9pm I believe. If you e-mail the hotel before you arrive, they will allow 1 reservation. We did this 2 days before leaving and had a reservation set up for the first evening. You can make reservations at the hotel from 12pm-4pm daily for two days so be sure to make them or you may be dining at the buffet each night. After reading some of the reviews, we didn't think the food was going to be good but I would have to say compared to other AI's we have stayed at, it was quite good. Probably liked Sir Oliver's the best, The others like the Japanese, Brazilian and Mexican were good ... not great ... but it is AI. As well, the buffet seemed quite good in comparison as well. We had stayed at the Iberostar Lindo 1 1/2 years ago, and enjoyed the food here much more. 4 out of 5 Spa: My girlfriend loves the spa, and always goes wherever we stay. Her comments were that it was one of the best AI spas that she had visited. Not as good as some of the places at home, but better than her expectations. TIP - Ensure to enroll for your Riu club card as you will save 15% at the spa !!! 5 out of 5 Pool: This is one area that didn't meet our expectations. We love long windy pools that you can dissappear in, but the pool here though nice was small. The pools at the Iberostar are way better. 2 out of 5 Beach: As above, the beach was dissappointing. Out of all of our Carribean AI trips, I would say the Riu Palace had our least favorite beach. It was a bit small, and with the gate at the end didn't seem welcoming. 2 out of 5 Service: Once again, with the reviews was not expecting great service but I have to say I was very impressed by the service levels. This includes the restaurants, room cleaning, the bars ... everything. I would say it was the best service we received at any resort so far. One thing I did notice was that it didn't seem like anyone was tipping anywhere. Please tip these people, they are working very hard. We tipped about $5 for dinners, $5 daily for room cleaning, and tipped the guy stocking the fridge regulary. 5 out of 5 So overall a good trip. I would suggest that if your priorities are a great beach and pool, stay somwhere else. If not the Riu Palace would be a great choice. But for the same price, I thought the Iberostar Lindo was a much better choice/nicer hotel for our needs (PRO-Better pool and beach, CON-food and service not as food). As well, compared to the three trips we have had to Punta Cana, would recommend Punta Cana over the MExican Riviera but that is just our choice.

Reviews.Title: “Very relaxing stay in Playa!”
Reviews.Author: eshneken
Reviews.Content: My wife and I have returned after a 5 night stay at the Riu Palace Maya Riviera. We read a million of these reviews before going -- all I can say is that most of the negative reviews did have some sort of accuracy to them, but in looking back at them now they are so trivial that I can't believe people even cared about those things. Overall our experience was excellent. The hotel and grounds are absolutely stunning. The pool area is fantastic -- the best I have ever seen. We took a walk along the beach and popped into most of the other hotels in Playacar and none had facilities like this hotel. I was also very impressed with the level of service and friendlines of the staff. Perhaps the folks who wrote reviews complaining about the level of service are royalty who are used to servants waiting on them hand-and-foot. I don't know. The service was really quite excellent. We ate at the Japanese, Mexican, and Gourmet restaurants along with the buffet. The Japanese and Gourmet restaurants were excellent -- we found the Mexican restaurant skippable. The buffets were decent -- good for breakfast and lunch but a little repetitive when it came to dinner. If anything, the food would be the only weak part of this resort. Don't get me wrong -- it was by no means bad nor did it significantly detract from our vacation -- it was simply the only weak link in this fine place. If you are expecting a gourmet experience every meal, you will be dissapointed. If, however, you are going to relax and enjoy your vacation and you are happy with a good breakfast, decent lunch, and some nice dinners you will be pleased. The town of Playa Del Carmen is great and is even walkable from the resort (about 20 minutes walking) or a $5 cab ride. There are lots of great restaurants there -- check out Ula Gula on 5th Avenue and 10th street. If you're looking to party, the discobars on Calle 12 are very cool. If you choose to stay here, be assured that you won't be dissapointed. I can't imagine anyone having less than an above average experience here. tip -- if you are staying off season and they are not full, request a room facing the courtyard. if you are nice and they have space, they will accomodate you. the courtyard view is definitely better than the outside views....

Reviews.Title: “Learning curve”
Reviews.Author: karw
Reviews.Content: We just returned from celebrating our 37th anniversary. Hotel is beautiful as well as grounds/beach. Beds are way too firm and rooms, while lovely, have a musty smell. Food is good and huge variety but gets boring. Staff including housekeeping are wonderful but front desk lack attention. Need more and better activities/entertainment. Pools need to be cleaned more often. Best of all the RIU in Playa Del Carmen.

Reviews.Title: “Absolutely Perfect!”
Reviews.Author: dream2life
Reviews.Content: I did have high expectations prior to my trip. I went there with my kids and enjoyed every moment of our stay at this resort. Service was impecable - everyone was very attentive to any andevery need. Pool was great especially swim-up bar where they even served non-alcoholic drinks to my kids. Weather forecast was horrible but we had heavy rain only once there and enjoyed the great weather throughout our stay. Rooms were good (I kind of lacked ability to access the Internet first days but then quickly forgot about my Internet addiction thanks to the marvelous surroundings and ambiance of the hotel). I definitely will try going there again next year and will recommend this place to anyone, whether families with kids or couples.

Reviews.Title: “Go Riu!”
Reviews.Author: der44
Reviews.Content: Me and my numerous family stayed 8 days in this wonderful resort. We arrived and had some problems with the rooms that were not well booked, but after solving that everything was just great! The hotel is huge and nice (colonial but luxurious style), and the service is good. As we were so many we did not use the restaurant system every night, but the main buffet was simply great with food for all tastes! Rooms are large, nice, comfortable and with a perfect bathroom and an incredible balcony (my favourite!) for an after-beach recovering sleep. Excellent pool and beach with lots of activities! About location i cannot say much as it is placed on the beach, great! I highly highly recomend this awsome resort!!

Reviews.Title: “Classy Romantic Resort for Couples”
Reviews.Author: johnyhandful
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Riu Palace Riviera from October 20th-27th, 2006. I am a fussy traveller who expects a true five star experience to include quality lodging & also exemplary service. I am happy to report the Riu Palace surpassed expectations. The property is designed around a large courtyard, which features a very spacious outdoor bar and cafe style area. Taking drinks or wonderful coffees here in the morning or evening is reminiscent of sitting in the wonderful outdoor cafes of Rome or Paris. Many readers question whether or not the better value is the Riu Palace Mexico or the Riu Palace Riviera. Having spent time at both properties, it is my belief that the Riviera is superior to the Mexico in several respects. The hotels appear similar from the outside, the rack rate at the Riviera is somewhat higher than the Mexico, but until recently the Mexico has had better reviews. This confuses some people who don't know which to pick and choose from. Here's my opinion. 1. The pool at the Riviera is much larger than the Mexico. I like to do the occasional lap now and again, and this pool has plenty of room. 2. The a la carte meals in the evening are of greater variety and seem to be somewhat higher quality at the Riviera than the Mexico. Other couples that we spoke with that spent time at both properties (not just people who took a walkthrough) also seemed to be of this view. A well travelled group of people I met while here had spend time at the Riu Palace Las Americas in Cancun a few months before. They felt the Riviera food was to a much higher standard than the Cancun Las Americas. 3. I'm a real stuffy guy, and I'm pleased to report that the service at the Riviera is second to none. The resort is still quite new but now seems to have come through the initial growing pains that generally plague all new properties. In time, Riviera should certainly surpass the Mexico in terms of overall ratings. In the meantime, if you can book the Riviera for close to the same price as the Mexico, you should do so. Food. We ate at all four a la carte restaurants on the property that were open. There are two sittings per evening at each restaurant (6:30 and 8:45 pm or thereabouts) 1. The Japanese restaurant is not a Benihana or ichiban style (communal tables with a cooking show), but a more intimate dining experience. When we arrived at our table, a bottle of California zinfandel was still corked and chilling in a champagne bucket, along with an assortment of 1/2 litre bottles of pop. If we had wanted champagne (actually a decent spanish cava), merlot or cabernet sauvignon, the waiter was happy to oblige. Fresh Sushi arrived shortly thereafter. We had our choice of several very tasty main courses. We felt awfully spoiled at this restaurant. 2. Botofogo is a Brazilian barbeque. Meat is carved at the table, and you get a nice taste of six or seven meats on the menu. Its a fun experience. 3. The Mexican a la carte is very nice. There is a wide assortment of Mexican starter dishes buffet style to begin with, and you order a main course from the menu. We had the steak, done exactly to order and soft enough to cut with a fork. 4. Sir Olivers is the continental restaurant, and considered the hardest reservation to make. My wife had the shrimp and scallop dish and I had a filet mignon with baby potatoes. Really superb. The ambience of this restaurant is very romantic, and the service was over and above what we expected. Chilis steakhouse was not open at this time, as we went during low season. However, with steak offered at the Mexican restaurant and Sir Olivers, you will have plenty of choices to pick and choose from. When you make your reservations, the current policy is that you are allowed to make TWO dinner reservations per day. If you intend to try all four restaurants, it is therefore suggested that you book them over two days. Some groups showed up at the restaurants without reservations at the sittings. Provided that space was available, they were gladly accomodated. We went during shoulder season, so there is generally space, but during high season walk ins may have a harder time. The evening buffet restaurant is by far and away the BEST QUALITY I've eaten at in the Caribbean. Some suggest that when they walk in, they don't see buffet counters buckling under the accumulated weight of trough food, and seem disappointed. This is because much of what is offered is made freshly to order, and offered in individual portions. One evening, the buffet featured duck a l'orange, beef tenderloin, red snapper and marmelade glazed ham. Champagne flows freely at all times, and the waiters gladly accomodate any alcohol request. Shows: high quality cabaret style shows are held each night in a classy and romantic setting. Waiters/waitresses constantly offer to fill your glass while you watch. Prior to each show, a live band with an awfully good singer belts out an assortment of romantic salsa, bachata or merengue tunes for you to practise your moves. We counted 10 waiter/waitresses serving about 100 people one night at the show, which meant quick and efficient service. Rooms: the rooms are of fair size, with tasteful decor, a comfortable balcony, feature the usual RIU alcohol dispenser and plenty of cold beverages replenished frequently. For a pleasant change, there were more hangers in our room than we needed. Beach: quite nice. If you like snorkeling, I suggest that you walk about 25 yards to the right of the Riviera property. At the Wyndham, a man made sea wall (a fat sandbag) has been placed about 50 feet off the shore. This is slowly turning into a reef environment. Beginning snorkellers will see hundreds smaller fish on the deeper side of this wall, which is only 8 feet down. I saw plenty of parrot fish as well as small cuttlefish (squid) over a couple of days, which was fun. A couple of hints. If you want to see an interesting display of wildlife, walk over to the Riu Yucutan in the afternoons. At the back of the property, there is a thriving family of howler monkeys closer to the hotel lobby, living in the trees. They divide their time between the adjacent Iberostar Quetzal property and the Yucutan. The Yucutan also has a large agouti population ( they look somewhat like rats but are related to the guinea pig) which wander the property. Just leave a banana or fruit on the grass by some trees, and the agoutis will come out and eat it. They love fruit. For no haggle souvenirs, the Walmart in Playa Del Carmen is on the corner of 30th avenue and 8th street. Absolutely the cheapest alcohol, cigars and freshest coffee in the city. I bought 15 year old Matusalem rum at Walmart for 179 pesos ($16.50 U.S.) , which sells for $34 at the Cancun airport duty free shops. The exchange rate at Walmart also was better than the Cambios throughout town. DON'T buy so called "Cuban" cigars from any shop or vendor, unless the box has a holographic sticker of authenticity attached. The cuban government now places a holograph on genuine boxes (or the three and five packs) of cuban cigars. Even the Montecristos at the Riu don't have these holographs, and when I inspected the cigars, they were just pretty good looking fakes. Spend a lot less money, and just yourself get a decent Mexican cigar from the Walmart tobacco shop. Near the Walmart (on 10th street) are a host of internet cafes. Internet time is generally about 4 pesos for half an hour of use. At the Riu Hotel, it costs about 40 pesos for 15 minutes of internet time. So, if you are in a mood to compose a longer email, do it while you are in town on day trips. Phone cards. Buy a Telmex phone card from your tour rep. 22 minutes of long distance time is $10 U.S. Use it at the small shopping mall quite close to the Riu Palace Mexico, or at any Telmex phone. You'll save a lot of money when compared to the hotel phone. Waiters and waitresses at the hotel may often address you first in Spanish, and switch to English if you don't know Spanish. Don't be alarmed if you don't speak much/any Spanish, as they are all pretty fluent in English. I rather of liked it, as it gave me a chance to practise my limited spanish. TIPPING: My wife and I were actually surprised/shocked/ at how little tipping we saw while at the Riu. Virtually the only other people we saw that provided anything to the staff were generally Canadian. Apparently, some persons take tour operator brochures quite literally when it is stated that tipping is included. People, please! Its a posh hotel! A certain gentleman from Houston actually asked me to translate his expectation to a waitress that he be given back $4.50 from a five dollar he gave her, after watching her run her run back and forth to the bar for an entire evening...serving a VERY large party. I was mortified for both him and the waitress serving him. I greatly appreciated their efforts to make my stay enjoyable. so, I I tipped $5 U.S. dollars at each a la carte restaurant, $2 for the maid each day and a few dollars each time for the breakfast, lunch and evening buffet waiter. It seemed awfully cheap for the quality of what I received. You receive the same great service whether or not you choose to tip. However, its a pretty swanky hotel, even by U.S. standards. Leaving $.25 or $.50 is just plain rude. Also, tipping the maid at the end of the week is a no no. Maids often change shifts mid week. Consequently the end of week tippers, probably wind up shorting one or more of their maids, and then provide a semi decent tip someone who has never actually made up your room. In closing, for us, the Riviera represented our best all around resort vacation in Mexico. I would certainly say that the hotel is nicer than the Royal Hideaway (just a few properties down), and certainly a cut above any other Riu property in the area. If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to drop me an email.

Reviews.Title: “Best Caribbean vacation yet!”
Reviews.Author: BestTimes
Reviews.Content: Pat & Barry, Oakville, ON. We stayed at the RPRM Oct 16-23.We have stayed at other Riu's before but not a palace. This truly was a palace. We truly loved everything. Upon arrival they had a drink waiting for us, we had our welcome briefing immediately so we could get info/tips on everything. We arrived approx 12:00 noon and many people didn't get rooms until 3:00 so do pack your bathing suit, sunscreen, etc in your carryon. Everything in this hotel is spotless, they are always cleaning. All staff extremely helpful, always want to please you. We couldn't believe everyone that worked there always had a smile. Beach very close to hotel/pool and very nice. Pool is spectacular. Rooms were very clean. All food whether buffet or a la carte absolutely out of this world. They have 5 a la carte restaurants and we would rate them in this order excellent to good: Japanese, Gourmet (Sir Oliver's), Brazilian, Steak House, Mexican but buffet very good as well. All of the waiters whether at beach, pool, nightly entertainment, inside hotel etc excellent.. We had a lot of fun with Jose and Rene mostly - so nice, very hard working, just made our vacation. We read all of the reviews prior to leaving and don't know where they came up with the bad reviews. I do have one comment -- they give you complimentary safes. DO keep everything in your safe at all times -- we left our digital camera in our beach bag unattended in our room while having breakfast and it went missing. BEWARE of your valuables. We found everyone very friendly and met a wonderful couple from Ontario Cam & Carm and had a lot of laughs. Check this wonderful resort out for yourself.

Reviews.Title: “Great Service / OK Rooms”
Reviews.Author: VacationBeachBum
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Riu from 10/15 thru 10/20. The hotel is very beautiful and conviently located near Playa Del Carmen. It's a ten minute walk from the hotel to the Cozumel ferry. The service was great. We were well taken care of while relaxing by the pool and beach or enjoying the nightly entertainment. The wait staff was very attentive and was always quick to deliver drinks. The restaurants were very nice and the food was good. The hotel provides a variety of food choices; Japanese, Brazilian BBQ, and Mexican, to name a few. We found the service at the restaraunts to be very good. Please be aware that you must make dinner reservations for all restaurants other than the buffet. You are allowed to make reservations for 2 nights per day. Sadly, the rooms were the only downside of our experience with this hotel. First, the beds were a little hard for my taste. Also, the room had a very musty smell; it had a hint of fertilizer or insect spray. We requested another room and were moved, but the new room had the same smell. Also, the hotel has neigboring hotels on either side and any room on the outside of the hotel has a view of these hotels; very few rooms have a full ocean view. Overall, we enjoyed our stay at the Riu Palace Riviera Maya. However, we will probably stay at a different hotel on our next trip to Playa del Carmen.

Reviews.Title: “Great food & hotel”
Reviews.Author: jblackwood
Reviews.Content: Josh & Erin Barrie, ON We loved this hotel. The pools were very nice, the beach was close to the hotel (not like the other Riu Palace). The sevice was excellent.
